body:
@fjy @xvrl in the syncup, we had a small discussion regarding whether to use mysql in the examples or not. I consider the example setup a experimentation/prototype phase setup and it should be as simple as possible so using derby should be fine.
Please merge if you agree or just close if you believe we should stick to using mysql in the examples.
close and reopen to rebuild
I have tried removing long sleeps. Please see it is OK now, in the worst case the part of the tests that requires sleep can be removed.
@pjain1 can you pls squash your commits?
@anwenxu @cheddar  not done looking through it yet, but are there any tests at all?
@himanshug done

By "rejected" do you mean dropped because they are unparseable, or outside of the expected interval, or something like that?

If the rejected events tracking is going to be something not-pluggable, I think the round robin buffer is best. If it's pluggable then I think it's probably fine for the round-robin buffer to be the only builtin implementation (unless whoever's implementing it wants to do something else too).
a simple test to verify the behaviour would be nice.

Agree that a test would be nice, I could do one at some point before the PR is merged. i.e., Soon™

For now though does the general approach seem reasonable? Especially in the context of #1350?
LGTM.

My concern with making it pluggable is that while making the event logging could be pluggable, the method by which the events are fetched may not be so. For example, if I have one implementation which emits the events locally to a bound buffer, and another implementation which emits the events over the network, then there is not a clear way (to me at least) to have a unified impl for reading back the rejected events. For a local buffer it could be easy to put in an endpoint, but then would you also want that endpoint to read from the kafka topic if you had a kafka emission impl?

That's kind of how TaskLogs works. The interface there is:

``` java
  public Optional<ByteSource> streamTaskLog(String taskid, long offset) throws IOException;
  public void pushTaskLog(String taskid, File logFile) throws IOException;
```

There's also a SwitchingTaskLogStreamer that tries a bunch of different streamTaskLog implementations until one works. The reason for that is that task logs might be on S3 (if a task ended) or might be on the middle manager (if the task is still running).

But, I think that level of complexity is probably not needed for this, and it would be fine to have it not pluggable and just do the bounded buffer thing.

looks like a genuine problem. however, it is more of an extension mechanism problem than the code being fixed here which is prone to failure in various situations requiring other FileSystem schemes than hdfs and local.
I think the problem is that when FIleSystem.get(..) is called, hadoo-hdfs.jar is not in the classpath for classloader(which is Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader()) used because it wasn't in the original classpath of the druid process but was a transitive dependency of druid-hdfs-storage extension. Actually, I could argue that this is a hadoop bug as well because it did not honor config.getClassLoader() and used Thread context classloader.  (otherwise https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1454 would have fixed this problem)

There is some work happening to remove dynamic loading of extensions and that should fix this issue eventually. In the meantime, I would recommend just putting "hadoop classpath" manually on the classpath and that is what we [and most people] do.
actually, I created a bug for hdfs as well for using correct classloader https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/HDFS-8750
Test failed in java8. restarting
@himanshug took care of your comments and squashed them
LGTM
Is this covered in a test somewhere?
Added a test.

Hi @fjy we have been using the original code (simple consumer in Druid) in our production for budgeting control purpose for almost a year now. And I have tested the code reviewed version also with production data, with lots of restart, deprecation of persisted file so as to see it ingests from correct offset, and I was able to verify the indexed results.
+1, once travis is green :)
closing/reopening to rebuild, build failure seems unrelated
LGTM
close/reopen to rebuild

Some discussion happened on this issue last week. I think what needs to be done to make log rotation work along with archiving is:
- Modification of TaskLogPusher that allows pushing logs in chunks. This is technically an external interface, so we may have to consider whether it's likely that there are any implementations outside of druid-io.
- Modification of ForkingTaskRunner to use that new stuff and actually push logs in chunks.
- Some kind of TaskLogStreamer that can unify the log chunks and any fragment still present on the actual task runner.

Or if we just want to throw away old logs, it's a little simpler:
- Modification of ForkingTaskRunner to split logs into chunks and periodically delete old chunks. 
- When it's time to push logs (at the end of a task, if that ever happens) then merge & push whatever chunks haven't been deleted yet.

I think it would be nice to do the first thing, since I am a pack rat when it comes to logs, but I'm also wondering how other people feel.
close/reopen to rebuild

On Mon, Jul 13, 2015 at 10:38 PM, Nishant notifications@github.com wrote:

> +1
>

> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1519#issuecomment-121136953.

what would be the behaviour for case when there is a collision between realtime ingestion for late incoming data and any batch indexing job running at the same time ? Will it be the same as realtime ingestion wins over the batch job ?

@solimant do you mind signing the CLA: druid.io/community/cla.html
and we can merge this
@fjy I thought the CLA was for code contributions. I am only contributing to the documentation.
@solimant we had a discussion awhile ago and decided that CLAs for everything in the druid repo. Do you have a concern with the CLA? If so, we can discuss about it
Not at all, I just wasn't aware. Anyways, I've signed the CLA.
@solimant Thanks for the contrib!

It would depend on the priority you set, I think. I think most people would want priorities to be in this order:

1) Realtime
2) Normal batch ingestion
3) Reindexing/compaction batch ingestion

I think some people will differ on whether (1) and (2) should be the same priority or different priorities. IMO a reasonable default is for them to be different, so realtime indexing always preempts anything else. But, if there are sites that want to set (1) and (2) to the same priority (maybe they want to avoid liveness issues with batch) then that should be doable too. That would just mean that there's a potential of realtime ingestion stalling for a bit when a batch task is running.
@fjy My pleasure. Thank you for the support. I was wondering, when would this be published on druid.io?
Looking into it. It seems to me that curator TestingServer is not in a fresh state sometimes.

@cheddar @xvrl @drcrallen I think I have either replied or changed code to take care of all the individual comments. Please see if it looks OK.
If it does, then I will cleanup the commit history to make the PR merge ready.
@ubercow Thanks for the contrib! I have a few minor comments. Can I also request some tests similar to what is in FileTaskLogsTest and HDFSTaskLogsTest

There were some concerns that combiner usage may incur unwanted overhead in some situations where there is not enough to merge. We decided to add  "useCombiner" flag so that users can choose to be explicit about whether they want to use the combiner or not. By default, combiner is not used.
As an alternative, I could fork this off to its own task runner type.
@xvrl added a "useCombiner" flag to HadoopTuningConfig for explicity enabling combiner. By default, it is set to false.

Talked a bit to @himanshug and we thought that optimistic locking for batch is going to be simpler to implement than priorities.

I think for that to work we'll need some way of getting versions to tasks other than LockAcquireAction. Possible splitting that into two steps- one that optimistically gets a version for an interval and one that actually locks the interval.
@pjain1 can you please look into this one.

Is there anything that makes sure the RTR doesn't fail the tasks when the MM goes offline? Normally it does that as soon as the ephemeral task status announcements disappear, which would happen immediately.
@gianm : no not yet
@drcrallen it should be enough to just make the Jetty query thread pool to use daemon threads, so we don't have to worry about it outside of the lifecycle.
Fixed jetty to have daemon threads and allow cleaner shutdown
Note : https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/1521 adds the ability to shutdown Peons via an HTTP endpoint.
@solimant Thanks for this catch. Do you mind submitting a PR with the fix?
Test failed on zk consistency issues. Restarting
@fjy Sure, I will do that.

I've been back and forth with @cheddar about when is the appropriate time to use URIs vs other object serialization formats. In general I think that URIs are most great and essential when communicating with outside tools, but when used purely for internal stuff, sticking to Druid's commonly used internal object SerDe (Jackson - Json) is much preferred when possible.

Since this is implementing a custom firehose(factory) json structure, can you just put the required object definitions there, and not use a URI?

That is to say, unless you can show that either:
1. a URI like this is needed for inter-tool operability
2. A URI like this provides significant functionality improvments

... then we should be using Json structures to describe objects.

I love URIs, and think they are a handy way to communicate resource information between multiple tools, but don't think we should be inventing our own URIs.

Cool. could it be called "blobs" (or similar) instead of "uris"? otherwise that format works for me. 

FYI, if you're going to have a list for a firehose you'll need to have pretty good rules for ordering and what to do about errors, and what happens if there's interruptions and restarts. Imagine JVM crash 3/4 of the way through your first container, what do you want to have the system do?
@fjy I've created the pull request.
Fixes #1525
@himanshug sure
@fjy can we please remember to squash commits before merging?
@xvrl that was my fault, i got used to all PRs being squashed :)
@sherry-q Thanks for the catch and the fix! Do you mind filling out our CLA (http://druid.io/community/cla.html) and I can merge this

@anwenxu I am not doubting the code works but I think it is good practice to write unit tests for large contributions of code. This makes it much easier to refactor the code later on and fix bugs with confidence, knowing our changes won't inadvertently break something. Furthermore, we decided with @cheddar that we would try our best to make sure Druid's code coverage does not go down with new contributions.
Turns out all the tests did silly thing like "extract first character" or "retain missing values" which can be applied as many times as it wants.
do we need a test for groupBy as well?
@xvrl No turns out it is covered, I'll put in a PR to make extra sure though.
@drcrallen any indication of performance improvement?
@fjy  @sherry-q is in our team, should be on the corp cla.  @cheddar can you please add her if not already.
@himanshug Thx :)
@sherry-q If you haven't done so already, you may want to check out https://groups.google.com/forum/#!searchin/druid-development/credit/druid-development/1Zs3Vd9LHCQ/cadqT73UeVcJ

@fjy Thanks for the tip!
@himanshug @cheddar Thanks!
@cheddar @xvrl @drcrallen hey guys what is the status of getting this PR merged?
@fjy For what part?
@drcrallen by not applying the extraction fn multiple times, is there a performance improvement?
@fjy Probably, but it should only be for dimension extraction. I do not have numbers for it.
@drcrallen i think all your review comments are taken care of.

Alright, I think I've addressed all of your concerns. I'd be happy to squash if you guys want, I made a lot of commits just to make the changes easy to follow.

@drcrallen as for your concern about rules, I really don't know how to approach this. It should be noted that this behaves similarly to the S3 firehose so whatever changes we make here we should probably make there for consistency. I don't see this firehose being applicable for realtime scenarios, only indexing service and correct me if I'm wrong, but it's my understanding that won't push segments until the task completes with a "Success" status. The firehose doesn't delete files either, so I believe the answer to your question is just "Run the task again"

@himanshug  Yep thanks

Please squash then :+1:
@drcrallen I have cleaned up the commit history already. commits in the history now represent key logical stages of the development which I would like to preserve.
